variant.question: Which statement regarding the relationship between traffic load and range is correct?

options.text: The traffic load can be limited by the desired range.
The Maximum Landing Mass is basically equal to the Maximum Zero Fuel Mass.
The maximum zero fuel mass limits the maximum quantity of fuel.
The maximum traffic load is not limited by the reserve fuel quantity.

variant.question: The traffic load is a part of the..
Mass for individual passengers (to be carried on an aeroplane) may be determined from a verbal statement by or on behalf of the passengers if the number of:

options.text: passenger seats available is less than 10.
passenger seats available is less than 20.

variant.question: The standard mass for a child is:

options.text: 35 kg for holiday charters and 38 kg for all other flights.
30 kg for holiday charters and 35 kg for all other flights.

variant.question: Refer to figure or CAP 696 file. An aeroplane fitted with 106 passenger seats operates a holiday charter flight within the European region. For this flight, the passengers on board are 46 males, 38 females, 12 children, 5 infants (taking the same seat with their parents) and 62 checked baggage. The Operator uses standard masses for passengers (all adults) and checked baggage and there are no cargo items in the holds. What is the Traffic Load of this flight?

The operator of an aircraft equipped with 50 seats uses standard masses for passengers and baggage
 During the preparation of a scheduled flight a group of passengers present themselves at the check-in desk, it is apparent that even the lightest of these exceeds the value of the declared standard mass.

options.text: The operator must determine the actual mass of such passengers by weighing or by adding an adequate increment.
The operator may use the standard masses for the balance but must correct these for the load calculation.
The operator may use the standard masses for the load and balance calculation without correction.
The operator is obliged to use the actual masses of each passenger.

variant.question: The operator of an aircraft equipped with 50 seats uses standard masses for passengers and baggage. During the preparation of a scheduled flight a group of passengers present themselves at the check-in desk, it is apparent that even the lightest of these exceeds the value of the declared standard mass.

options.text: The operator must determine the actual mass of such passengers by weighing or by adding an adequate increment.
The operator may use the standard masses for the balance but must correct these for the load calculation.
The operator is obliged to use the actual masses of each passenger.
The operator may use the standard masses for the load and balance calculation without correction.

variant.question: Traffic load is the difference between

options.text: the take-off mass and the operating mass.
the take-off mass and the basic empty mass.
the operating mass and the basic empty mass.
the take-off mass and the basic empty mass plus trip fuel.

variant.question: The operator must establish the mass of the Traffic Load (TL)

options.text: By actual weighing or determine the mass of the traffic load in accordance with standard masses as specified in EASA AIR OPS.
By using an appropriate method of calculation as specified in the EASA AIR OPS.
Prior to embarking on the aircraft.
Prior to initial entry into service.

variant.question: Traffic Load is the:

options.text: Zero Fuel Mass minus Dry Operating Mass.
Dry Operating Mass minus the disposable load.
Dry Operating Mass minus the Variable Load.
Take-off Mass minus Zero Fuel Mass.

variant.question: By adding to the Basic Empty Mass (BEM) the following fixed necessary equipment for a specific flight (catering, safety and rescue equipment, fly away kit, crew), we get
The "TRAFFIC LOAD" is defined as:

options.text: the Total Mass of passengers, baggage and cargo, including any non revenue load.
the Total Mass of passengers, baggage, cargo and usable fuel.
the Total Mass of flight crew, passengers, baggage, cargo and usable fuel.
the Total Mass of crew and passengers excluding any baggage or cargo.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 You are about to depart for a domestic commercial flight, with an aircraft having a capacity of 2 flight crew members and 10 passengers. As part of your pre-flight calculations, you need to compute the Traffic Load in accordance with standard passenger and baggage masses as defined in the annex. What is the Traffic Load, given the following information?Flight crew: 2 
 Male passengers: 2 
 Female passengers: 3 
 Baggage: 6 pieces, with a total mass of 63 kg 
 Hand baggage: 3 pieces 
 Standard mass for a flight crew member: 85 kg

Refer to the annex.
You are about to depart for a domestic commercial flight, with an aircraft having a capacity of 2 flight crew members and 10 passengers. As part of your pre-flight calculations, you need to compute the Traffic Load in accordance with standard passenger and baggage masses as defined in the annex. What is the Traffic Load, given the following information?
Flight crew: 2
Male passengers: 2
Female passengers: 3
Baggage: 6 pieces, with a total mass of 63 kg
Hand baggage: 3 pieces
Standard mass for a flight crew member: 85 kg
Traffic Load (TL) is a part of
In determining the Dry Operating Mass of an aeroplane it is common practice to use standard mass values for crew. These values are:

options.text: flight crew 85 kg, cabin crew 75 kg each. These are inclusive of a hand baggage allowance.
flight crew 85 kg, cabin crew 75 kg each. These do not include a hand baggage allowance.
flight crew (male) 88 kg (female) 75 kg, cabin crew 75 kg each. These include an allowance for hand baggage.
flight crew (male) 88 kg (female) 75 kg, cabin crew 75 kg each. These do not include an allowance for hand baggage.

variant.question: An aircraft performing a line service between two airports within one and the same state is carrying 12 passengers on a given day. The total number of passenger seats is 19. What standard mass must be used for the passengers' baggage?

options.text: Standard masses must not be used.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 You are about to depart for a commercial flight, with an aircraft having a flight crew of 7 members and 115 passengers. As part of your pre-flight calculations and given the following information, you need to calculate the Traffic Load in accordance with the standard passenger and baggage masses, as defined in the annex.Flight crew: 4 male & 3 female 
 Male passengers: 70 
 Female passengers: 35 
 Children: 10 
 Baggage: 62 items 
 Standard mass for a flight crew member: 85 kg 
 Non-revenue load: 500kg
For an aircraft having 16 passenger seats, if no hand luggage is carried, how much weight may be deducted from the standard passenger weights for passengers over 12 years old?
Standard masses may be used for the computation of mass values for baggage if the aeroplane:
On any flight identified as carrying a significant number of passengers whose masses, including hand baggage, are expected to exceed the standard passenger mass the operator

options.text: Must determine the actual mass of such passengers or add an adequate increment to each of such passengers.
Must determine the actual mass of such passengers.
Need only determine the actual masses or apply an increment if the Take-off mass is likely to be exceeded.
Must add an adequate mass increment to each of such passengers.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 Airbus A320 has a seating capacity of 162 passengers, and it is scheduled to operate a holiday charter Commercial Air transport flight within Europe. The loading manifest shows the following information:Passengers An: 152 adults + 8 children + 5 infants (carried on the same seat of the parent) 
 Passenger baggage: 132 pieces 
 Freight: 1020 kgIf the operator uses standard masses for passengers (all adults) and checked baggage, the actual traffic load of this flight is...
Crew baggage is considered to be
Once the mass and balance documentation has been signed prior to flight

options.text: Acceptable last minute changes to the load must be documented.
Documented last minute changes to the load may be incorporated.
The documentation is not signed prior to flight.

variant.question: For the purposes of mass and balance EASA AIR OPS defines a child as a person aged:

options.text: of 2 years but not having reached their 12 birthday.
of 3 years but not having reached their 12 birthday.
of 2 years but not having reached 15 years of age.
of 3 years but not having reached their 15 birthday.

Standard passenger masses used for a holiday charter flight are:

options.text: Male 83 kg, Female 69 kg, or an average mass of Adult person 76 kg.
Child up to the age of 12 years 30 kg.
Average mass of adult person 84 kg.

variant.question: Ref; CAP696 Section 1 Page 5. On an aeroplane with a seating capacity of more than 30, it is permissible to use standard mass values for computing the total mass of passengers. If the flight is not a holiday charter, the mass value which may be used for an adult is:
The responsibility for determination of the mass of special operational equipment and crew members included within the Dry Operating Mass lies with...

options.text: the authority of the state of registration.
the person compiling the weighing schedule.

Male 88kg. 
Female 70 kg. 
Child 35 kg. 
Infant 6 kg.
The standard mass value to be used for hold baggage is 14 kg per piece.

Baggage in  hold number 4: 120 pieces.

options.text: no cargo can be loaded in hold number 1.

 A turboprop aeroplane having 36 passenger seats operates a domestic Commercial Air Transport flight carrying a rugby team of 28 sportsmen. Each of these players has one checked baggage and the average mass of these people is 115 kg. Determine the mass of the Traffic Load for this flight.
Ref CAP 696 Section 1 page 5. On an aeroplane with 20 or more seats engaged on an inter-continental flight, the 'standard mass' which may be used for passenger baggage is:
When determining the Dry Operating Mass of a 19 seat aircraft used on a holiday charter, select the correct mass allowance for a cabin crew member:
Standard mass as used in the computation of passenger load establish the mass of a child as

options.text: 35 kg irrespective of age provided they occupy a seat.
35 kg for children over 2 years occupying a seat and 10 kg for infants (less than 2 years) occupying a seat.
35 kg for children over 2 years occupying a seat and 10 kg for infants (less than 2 years) not occupying a seat.
35 kg only if they are over 2 years old and occupy a seat.

variant.question: If standard mass tables are being used for checked baggage and a number of passengers check in baggage that is expected to exceed the standard baggage mass, the operator:

options.text: Must determine the actual mass of such baggage by weighing or adding an adequate mass increment.
Must determine the actual mass of such baggage by weighing or by deducting an adequate mass increment.
Determine the actual masses of such baggage.
Need make no alterations if the Take-off mass is not likely to exceeded.

variant.question: If individual masses are used, the mass of an aeroplane must be determined prior to initial entry into service and thereafter

options.text: at intervals of 4 years if no modifications have taken place.
only if major modifications have taken place.

variant.question: Which statement is correct about securing of TRAFFIC LOAD?

options.text: Containers and pallets can remain on rollers within tracks if they are secured by latches.

The dangers regarding unsecured traffic load during rotation while taking-off include a forward movement of the centre of gravity (CG) outside of the CG limits but also any possibly damage to the bulkheads of the aircraft.
Unit load devices (ULD) must be restrained with straps to specific tie-down points in the floor of the cargo compartment.
The traffic load must be restrained from moving throughout the whole flight, so that only previously calculated movements of the centre of gravity (CG) due to fuel burn can occur.
